Award.AwardTitle: BioScholars II: Supporting Women from Underserved Communities in the Study of Biological Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: BioScholars II, a program of scholarships for 20 academically talented but financially needy students at Pine Manor College, builds on the successes of its predecessor, BioScholars I. It supports such students not only financially, but also academically and personally, to enable them to continue their studies of biology, to graduate, and to enter the workforce or continue in their scientific studies. As a small, all-women's school enrolling a majority of local, low-income, ethnic minority students, Pine Manor targets its support in demonstrably effective ways. In particular, all students are expected to complete a capstone internship, and for BioScholars, this is expected to involve research at one of the colleges, universities, or industries in the Boston area. Teaching postdoctoral fellows from Sackler School of Biomedical Science at Tufts University offer seminar courses in advanced biomedical subjects to BioScholars and other interested students. Talks by visiting speakers, a Science Club, a Sophomore Honors Colloquium, peer and faculty mentoring, and early intervention for students experiencing difficulties round out the program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This goal of this initiative was to increase the number of students from underserved populations who enter into STEM careers.  Our career focus was biomedical research.  NSF funding provided scholarships and academic enrichment services; the college provided focused mentoring, acacemic advising and research experiences to a population of first generation college students from traditionally underserved communities. The specific objectives were to increase the retention of science majors, improve support services, increase the availability of research experiences and increase the number and diversity of students entering the biomedical workforce.  The  NSF BioScholars were biology majors expressing an interest in STEM careers or biomedical research who were recognized by the biology faculty as students of promise.  However, students' understanding of these careers was minimal. Research studies have shown that students who hail from underserved communities are aware of clinical healthcare careers, but are uninformed about research.    We report that we have accomplished these objectives. Our most striking result is that at least 50% of these NSF BioScholars are either currently working in research, or are intending to do so. 

Twelve rising sophomore students were chosen and have received support throughout the remainder of their college years. All have been retained and 10 have graduated. The remaining two encountered unavoidable disruptions in their college semesters and will complete their credits this fall 2016.

All students received the planned academic tutoring from a knowledgeable, energetic, student-savvy and research-experienced tutor.  All students created semester academic plans that were reviewed and frequently discussed throughout the semester with the PI.  The PI served as academic advisor and mentor for these awardees and met routinely with all students throughout all semesters.  Those awardees who have graduated present a mean GPA of 3.2+0.4 (median 3.17). 50% of them earned graduation honors:  2 cum laude, 1 magna cum laude, 2 summa cumlaude. 

A semester-long internship is an academic responsibility of all seniors at Pine Manor College. The weekly 16 hours of work at the site are augmented by a weekly seminar for which students have academic responsibilities.  Per the objectives of this initiative, all NSF BioScholars completed their internships in research environments.  

Our single most important result is that fully 6 NSF BioScholars are either currently working in research environments or are planning to do so.  This high percentage (50%) of students choosing to launch a research career is unusual. We attribute this to numerous events:

  • Research Career Literacy: NSF BioScholars participated in a special sophomore colloquium. The goal of this colloquium was to increase students' awareness of STEM careers, focusing on biomedical research. Guest speakers from biotechnology, basic research and education led the students through a series of learning objectives aimed to increase their awareness and understanding of research jobs and careers.  Each student created an electronic academic portfolio and presented it at the end of the semester.  These portfolios served as the foundation for each student's curriculum vitae and job resume.
  • Research Literature and Critical Thinking:  NSF BioScholars worked with the tutor when preparing their research papers in their biology courses, but specifically their senior capstone course research papers. A main goal of these senior projects is to learn to critically evaluate the primary  literature, which enforces an understanding of the nature of research. This research paper and the work with the NSF-designated tutor measurably increased students' awareness of and ability to use the primary literature
  • Research Exposure: The mandated Pine Manor College insternships of our NSF BioScholars were in labs at the Sackler School of Graduate Biomeical Sciences at Tufts University, MIT, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Boston University Medical Center and Pine Manor College. The research projects spanned a range:  cancer research, plant nanotechnology, pathology, eukaryotic cell RNA processing, liver lipid storage disease, virology and academic institutional quantitative research. The PI was in contact with site supervisors and visited each site in person.  By the students' own statements, these internships, more than anything else, helped them to understand the path that leads to a productive research career.
  • Networking and Careeer Development:  The NSF BioScholars PI hosted an annual meet-and-greet-and networking luncheon for all BioScholars and relevant faculty and staff at the college. The Office of Career Development provided specific input and feedback for the BioScholars.   NSF BioScholars were required to attend all guest lectures from Boston area scientists in the Biology Program and at two of these lectures resulted in an internship opportunity. All NSF BioScholars attended the annual STEM career fair hosted on our campus by postdoctoral research fellows from Tufts University.

In their senior portfolio essays and interviews at graduation, the NSF BioScholars credit this program with opening their eyes to the challenging but rewarding world of research, helping them experience it, and envisoin themselves as part of it.  Profiles and videos of the NSF BioScholars are on the Pine Manor College website:  www.pmc.edu
